In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Vinod K. Valsalam" <vkv@...> wrote:
>
> 
> Hi eve=
ryone!
> 
> I have some comments based on my recent work with Risto Miikkul=
ainen
> here at UT Austin.  I evolved controller networks for quadruped and=

> hexapod robots focusing on modularity.  The literature suggests that
> l=
eaky integrators are useful because of their richer dynamics, and
> therefo=
re they use CTRNN networks to generate the oscillatory patterns
> required =
for walking.  However, confirming what Ken said, I have found
> that they a=
re not necessary when joint angles are provided.  In this
> case, the requi=
red oscillations with proper phase relations between
> legs are generated b=
y the overall dynamics of the modular controller.
> 
> The modular controll=
er uses the same module for each leg, which allows
> its behavior to be exp=
lained in terms of coupled cell systems, which
> are dynamical systems used=
 by Martin Golubitsky, Ian Stewart and
> others to model central pattern ge=
nerators in animals.  In effect, the
> modular controller is a neural netwo=
rk implementation of their coupled
> cell system, each cell corresponding t=
o a module of the network.
> Although I used it for a quadruped, they used =
the same coupled cell
> system to model biped locomotion.  So you might als=
o find it useful.
> The details and references are in our forthcoming GECCO=
 paper:
> 
>      http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers/valsalam.gecco08=
.pdf
> 
> The videos mentioned in the paper are available here:
> 
>      h=
ttp://www.dailymotion.com/walkingtables
> 
> Vinod
> 
> 
> At Wed, 14 May 2=
008 16:44:03 -0000,
> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> > 
> > Peter C's message bri=
ngs up another issue that might be useful to
> > Peter B:  For ambulation, =
it might be more effective to use leaky
> > integrator neurons than the usu=
al feedforward neurons that are used in
> > most ANN models.  The leaky int=
egrators are better for precise timing.
> >  However, they may not be neces=
sary if joint angles are being provided
> > as input.  But when joint angle=
s are not provided, I do not think I
> > have ever seen a regular recurrent=
 ANN (i.e. non-leaky or not some
> > other special type of neuron) be able =
to make something walk.  In
> > fact, the "flailing" motions are often redu=
ced significantly by leaky
> > integrator neurons.  Tyler Streeter saw this=
 when he worked on his
> > biped with NEAT, which actually stopped flailing=
 after switching to
> > leaky integrators.  However, in his project the net=
work had no inputs
> > and worked entirely through internal pattern generat=
ion.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" =
<petar_chervenski@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi Peter,
> > > 
> > > I cannot =
add more to what Ken said, this is an entirely new
field and 
> > > a cutti=
ng edge of research but I suggest you take a look at my NEVH 
> > > project=
 as well (it is located in the files section in this group). 
> > > It is w=
ritten in C++ and utilizes HyperNEAT for constructing the 
> > > phenotypes=
. It also uses leaky integrators for the phenotype neuron 
> > > model. The=
 outputs there are not joint torques, but the desired
angle 
> > > of the j=
oint.
> > > It might be helpful to you, since we are both trying to achieve=
 the 
> > > same thing actually :)
> > > By the way I want to ask you if we=
 could join forces to collaborate 
> > > on such a project because it is a =
very interesting thing and I have 
> > > some experience with it. You can c=
ontact me in Skype (spookey85) if 
> > > you agree. 
> > > 
> > > Peter Che=
rvenski
> > >

errington@> 
> > > wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Thanks for your quick response Ke=
n!

=

this =

> > > domain.
> > > > 
> > > > Heres a linux only version that I was worki=
ng on recently, its 
> > > really
> > > > messy and I'm sure my code can us=
e a LOT of improvement (I was
kind 
> > > of
> > > > learning as I went alo=
ng). I only wrote the toribash-esque 
> > > experiment
> > > > and a few ch=
anges and features added to python-neat. The actual
> > > > python-neat bac=
kend is written by Cesar Gomez and is really 
> > > terrific,
> > > > as py=
thon has a certain elegance about it that makes it seem
easier 
> > > to
> =
> > > grasp. 
> > > > 
> > > > In order to get it to work you need to downl=
oad the linux
version of
> > > > Command Line Breve:
> > > > http://www.spi=
derland.org/download.php
> > > > Then unzip this in the breve_2.7.2/ direct=
ory:
> > > > http://peter.berrington.googlepages.com/tori.7z
> > > > 
> > >=
 > To evolve, open a shell and navigate to the breve directory, then 
> > >=
 call
> > > > the ToriExp with python, like this:
> > > > python tori/toriE=
xp.py
> > > > To view the last best individual, instead type this:
> > > > =
./bin/breve tori/viewlastbest.py
> > > > 
> > > > Theres a HUGE amount of p=
arameters for which I have no idea
what the
> > > > good values are. The cr=
eator of Toribash is giving me a
description 
> > > of
> > > > how his game=
 works but is not at all forthcoming with the specific
> > > > implementati=
on details; I suppose he is reluctant to give away
code
> > > > for somethi=
ng he makes money on, but it's frustrating as his
game is
> > > > actually =
very well balanced, allowing some very nimble and natural
> > > > looking a=
crobatics. Trial and error is probably the only
solution at
> > > > this st=
age.
> > > > 
> > > > I encourage people to fool around with this; I'm a co=
mplete
beginner
> > > > to programming this kind of stuff and I've got a lo=
t of really
> > > > terrible code I'm sure, so please submit any changes th=
at you
think
> > > > would make sense.
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > --- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > >=
 Hi Peter, that's a good question and of course learning to 
> > > control =
a 
> > > > > virtual creature with novelty search is a complicated issue
(a=
nd 
> > > an 
> > > > > appealing idea as well). 
> > > > > 
> > > > > Firs=
t, you have to deal with all the representational and 
> > > physical 
> > =
> > > issues outside of novelty search, like how many inputs, how
many 
> >=
 > > > outputs, and whether the body itself is not physically
flawed in 
> =
> > > > some way (which is possible).  As you are experiencing, the 
> > > =
> > inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive even with feature 
> > > > > se=
lection.  It is also possible that HyperNEAT could be useful 
> > > > > bec=
ause it does not care about the # inputs or outputs (and can 
> > > > > pot=
entially exploit geometric regularities), but configuring
the 
> > > > > su=
bstrate then becomes the challenge.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Assuming all of th=
at stuff is set up well with whatever system, 
> > > then 
> > > > > novelt=
y search is a potentially winning approach.  Yet as you 
> > > point 
> > >=
 > > out there are some big questions there as well.  In fact, we
are 
> > =
> > > currently trying to provide the best answers to these questions 
> > =
> in 
> > > > > ongoing research, but some general principles might help fo=
r
now: 
> > > > > 
> > > > > First, the archive in novelty search does not =
not need to
contain 
> > > > > every point ever visited.  Therefore, it ten=
ds to grow much 
> > > slower 
> > > > > than the #of evaluations.  However=
, if it is indeed getting too 
> > > big  
> > > > > then it is not unreaso=
nable to collapse some of the archive 
> > > points, 
> > > > > although th=
ere is no standard method yet for how that should be 
> > > > > done.  But =
we have reason to believe there will be effective
and 
> > > > > simple way=
s to do that.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Second, the issue of one individual look=
ing different just 
> > > because 
> > > > > of a phase difference in effec=
tivley the same behavior is 
> > > > > complicated.  For certain phase disa=
parities, the two
individuals 
> > > > > won't look all that different, but=
 it is true that at some 
> > > > > disparity, they may look very different=
.  Yet it is not clear 
> > > > > whether that fact is actually problematic=
 to the novelty search 
> > > or 
> > > > > not, because it would simply re=
ward both types of behavior.  It 
> > > is 
> > > > > possible that the pha=
se difference is a result of some useful 
> > > > > genotypic change, which=
 could make it a stepping stone to 
> > > something 
> > > > > better.  Or,=
 it is possible that it is superfluous information 
> > > and 
> > > > > si=
mply takes some extra time exploring the area around the
phase-
> > > > > s=
hifted individual.  So it is hard to say a priori whether
it is 
> > > a 
>=
 > > > > major concern.  We will have better answers to such
questions as 
=
> > > the 
> > > > > technique is further explored.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Ho=
wever, I agree that it would be nice to be able to say the
two 
> > > > > p=
hase-shifted individuals are largely the same if that is
indeed 
> > > > > =
what you want to say.  And for that, you would need a pattern-
> > > > > ma=
tching metric to compute behavioral distance, i.e. something 
> > > more 
>=
 > > > > sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance.  There are 
> > > c=
ertainly 
> > > > > such metrics available.  However, it's important to rec=
ognize 
> > > that 
> > > > > it is not evident at this point that ignoring=
 the phase
shift is 
> > > > > actually better than taking it into consider=
ation, because
taking 
> > > it 
> > > > > into consideration just means ad=
ding more information to the 
> > > novelty 
> > > > > landscape.
> > > > >=
 
> > > > > So overall I think novelty search is a very promising direction=
 
> > > to 
> > > > > go for such problems, but it is still in the realm of=
 research 
> > > (i.e. 
> > > > > there is no existing precedent), so it wi=
ll involve
considerable 
> > > > > trial and error to get it right until al=
l these issues are 
> > > fleshed 
> > > > > out more clearly.  Ultimately,=
 though, if our hypothesis about 
> > > > > novelty vs. fitness is correct,=
 novelty search may turn out
to be 
> > > > > the *only* way to get certain=
 highly complex types of
behavior to 
> > > > > evolve in some domains, whi=
ch is a sobering thought.  But if it 
> > > is 
> > > > > true, then there =
is not much to do other than try it.
> > > > > 
> > > > > ken
> > > > > 
> =
> > > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "peterberrington"
<peterberrington@> 
=
> > > > > wrote:
> > > > > >

velty search and its a

 the past couple of months I've been
working on

e controllers; specifically I have a
ragdoll rig

> > > > >=
 > I've set up in Breve Simulation Environment (available at

tp://spiderland.org )

 Toribash, a free
game

> > > > > > uses the open dynamics =
engine for physics, like breve.

he results I've been having discouraging; as

> > > > > > points =
out early on in his latest paper, trying to make a

 > biped usually results in it falling over perpetually. You can

> http://www.youtube.com/user/thehaircrow

> > > > > > Ultimate=
ly, I would like to package AI's with the Toribash
game 
> > > so
> > > > >=
 > that they are fun to play against in single player- I think 
> > > this =

> > > > > goal
> > > > > > is attainable despite being difficult.
> > > > =
> > Deception is a BIG problem here; if my fitness criteria is
time
> > > >=
 > > integrated distance from a goal, it encourages the
behaviour of 
> > >=
 the
> > > > > > "Tori" balancing in a stable configuration forever, rather=

than
> > > > > > walking, which is what I'm trying to encourage. As there
=
is 20 
> > > > > joints
> > > > > > in this rig, I am providing joint posit=
ion and velocity 
> > > information
> > > > > > for each joint, as well as =
a bias, a sine-wave, the x, y,
and z
> > > > > > components linear velocity=
 in the reference frame of the
Tori's 
> > > > > head,
> > > > > > and fina=
lly 3 variables which correspond to the vertical, 
> > > > > horizontal
> >=
 > > > > and forward orientation of the tori's head with respect to
world
>=
 > > > > > coordinates.  
> > > > > > The current experimental configuratio=
n I am started out as 
> > > a "pure"
> > > > > > ragdoll control where neu=
ral net outputs correspond directly 
> > > joint
> > > > > > velocity; a ta=
nh activation function is used to allow
positive 
> > > and
> > > > > > neg=
ative joint movement.
> > > > > > I then remodeled the experiment to perfor=
m as in the Toribash 
> > > game;
> > > > > > the net will receive inputs (=
and effect joint movements) only 
> > > > > every 10
> > > > > > time steps=
. More importantly, I increased the amount of
outputs 
> > > > > from
> > >=
 > > > 20 (1 per joint) to 40, in order to accomodate the 4 possible 
> > >=
 joint
> > > > > > actions which can occur on a turn: holding, relaxing, 
>=
 > > extending, 
> > > > > and
> > > > > > flexing. 
> > > > > > 
> > > > >=
 > Starting with a fully connected net, that gives a
staggeringly 
> > > hu=
ge
> > > > > > search space with over 1000 connections. Due to the 
> > > i=
mplementation,
> > > > > > its prohibitively slow to evolve large nets as t=
he
starting net 
> > > can
> > > > > > take up over 600mb of ram on the hea=
p. Realizing this was
a bit
> > > > > > ridiculous, I implemented feature s=
election and phased
pruning.
> > > > > > However, even with this, deception=
 seems to prevent any useful
> > > > > > behaviour; the Tori will always ge=
t stuck in ruts.

implementation of neat developed by Cesar

e GPL, which is available at

> python/

ar genome encoding taken
from the

> > > > > > optimize wei=
ghts but I haven't had much success meshing this

n I am home I will post my source files for

> > > > > > 
> > > > > > FINALLY, my question. The beha=
viour of a Tori is currently 
> > > > > represented
> > > > > > as a list o=
f 20 base 4 variables multiplied by the amount of 
> > > time
> > > > > > s=
teps the Tori is evaluated for. The novelty search method 
> > > proposed
>=

> =
> > ending
> > > > > > point then 
> > > > > > we add that point to a list =
of discovered behaviours. This 
> > > works 
> > > > > well
> > > > > > (I =
imagine) because a point isn't a lot of information to
hold.

>=

> >=
 > ragdoll
> > > > > > controllers for novelty; is there any compact encodi=
ng that

> > > > > > work? Since it often takes 25 000 seperate=

ht now, theres going to

uld appear that they were 100% unique,
